description.narrative: The Humanitarian Leadership Academy is a global learning initiative set up to facilitate partnerships and collaborative opportunities to enable people to prepare for and respond to crises in their own countries. The Academy is working with partners across the humanitarian sector and beyond and is supporting the needs of individuals organisations and communities by facilitating access to humanitarian learning resources platforms and tools.

mailing-address.narrative: 1 Saint Johns Lane, London EC1M 4AR, United Kingdom

description.narrative: 1. Establish a strong and sustainable learning provider network  through the provision of platforms, tools and advisory services to embed sustainable business models to facilitate accessible, sustained  effective high-quality learning provision for the sector
1. # of local/national and international organisations accessing Academy products, platforms or advisory services

comment.narrative: at least 28 organisations

Target is on track.
During the July to September 2018 reporting period, 4 additional organisations began accessing Academy learning products, bringing the total number of organisations to 58, of which 50% (29 organisations) are headquartered and predominantly operate in the Global South.
at least 14 organisations (in Academy-focused countries)*
at least 7 organisations (in Academy-focused countries)*

description.narrative: 2. Deliver for the humanitarian sector a contextualised professional development framework including context-specific career pathways aligned with a level-based competency framework (to support pathway skills, knowledge and experience required at each level)

1. Successful delivery of sector-based professional development framework (e.g. Humanitarian Passport Initiative/HPI) that ensures optimal: (1) buy-in from the sector; (2) local/national contextualisation and; (3) uptake and adoption within the sector in Academy-focus countries.

comment.narrative: Learning pathways developed and piloted.

Complete. The Academy has developed three learning pathways aligned to the Core Humanitarian Competencies Framework that are hosted on the Kaya learning platform: Humanitarian Essentials, Management Essentials, and Volunteer Essentials.
Draft sector-based professional development framework (e.g. Humanitarian Passport Initiative/HPI) framework agreed and roll-out commenced.
Inception phase research on competency framework carried out
HPass pilot completed by at least 25 organisations.

Target achieved.
The pilot concluded in September, engaging 35 organisations from globally diverse geographic regions, with services piloted including; a badge ‘factory’ enabling learning providers to create and issue badges in relation to specific courses or competencies, quality standards for providers of humanitarian learning and assessment, and an audit process to enable organisations to achieve accreditation against the standards.

description.narrative: 2. # of individuals utilising Academy-supported professional development (PD) framework (e.g., HPI) (to support pathway skills, knowledge and experience required at each level) including certified pathways recognised and adopted within by sector disaggregated by gender.

comment.narrative: Finalised PD framework developed and piloted within two Academy Centres.
Delayed
Learning, skills & experience of 1,500 individuals recognised (through professional certification or badges) against the competency framework (s).
Delayed. 253 individuals certified to date.

7,500 individuals engaged with competency framework (s). Learning, skills & experience of 500 individuals recognised, (through professional certification or badges) against the competency framework(s).

Target already achieved and surpassed.
The Academy has facilitated the engagement of 18,231 individuals with competency frameworks through the preparatory study guides created by the Practitioner Competencies Learning Centre .

description.narrative: 3. Develop/ facilitate access to global and local quality-assured and innovative learning through a wide variety of platforms (including a digital platform) for organic local communities of first responders recognising prior learning, experience & skills.
1. Rigorous Monitoring Evaluation and Learning (MEAL) processes for all learning content hosted by the Academy to ensure high quality, effective learning in place for the sector.

comment.narrative: All learning content hosted by the Academy assessed and evaluated and informing course-correction/ decision making for Academy Core strategy.
All learning content hosted by the Academy assessed and evaluated and informing course-correction/ decision making for Academy Core strategy.
Impact evaluations/ reviews in two Academy-focus countries informing Centre strategy for forthcoming year.
Complete. The Academy conducted two external evaluations in 2017.
Completion of four impact evaluations/reviews undertaken by/for the Academy (cumulative)

Target on track.
So far since 2016, the Academy has completed one impact evaluation for our Philippines BCP programme and one strategic and process review of the Alert and Ready Communities (ARC) programme in the Philippines. Additionally, the HSBC Humanitarian Learning Programme Impact Evaluation was completed mid-September and presented internally and externally to relevant stakeholders.

description.narrative: 2. Improved skills competency of engaged/enrolled individuals (disaggregated by gender/age/location)  who demonstrate improved skills capability as a result of completing Academy-supported learning based on pre/post competency (course-specific) assessments.

comment.narrative: 3,650 individuals (disaggregated by gender/age/ location/) assessed and demostrate improved skills capability due to Academy Learning (cumulative)
Exceeded. As of end December 2017, 6,813 individuals had indicated an improvement in skills competency as a result of the learning they engaged with via the Academy’s Kaya digital platform.
9,000 individuals (disaggregated by gender/age/ location/) assessed and demostrate improved skills capability due to Academy Learning (cumulative)

Target already exceeded.
By 30 Sept 2018, a total of 22,687 individuals, indicated improved skills capability due to Academy learning on the Kaya platform.
at least 250 individuals (disaggregated by gender/age/ location/) assessed and demostrate improved skills capability due to Academy Learning.
individuals (disaggregated by gender/age/ location/) assessed and demostrate improved skills capability due to Academy Learning.

description.narrative: 3. Expansive array of high-quality customised learning content, from leading providers, hosted or facilitated by Academy platforms, Centres and affiliates.

comment.narrative: 275 courses/ modules/ learning events
Exceeded. 363 courses and learning events have so far been made available by the Academy.
415 courses/ modules / learning events

Target already exceeded.
The Academy has so far made available 422 courses and learning events.
25 courses/ modules/ learning events
courses/ modules/ learning events

description.narrative: 4. Access to locally relevant content of under-represented/ marginalised content (i.e., gender, risk management, climate change adaptation)  made available within Academy-focus countries based on  outreach and engagement, needs assessments and market research.

comment.narrative: Under-represented content identified within 7 learning courses/ modules/ events hosted by the Academy.
Exceeded. As of end December 2017, the Academy had hosted eight learning pieces containing under-represented content, as defined in agreement with DFID.
Under-represented content identified within 12 learning courses/ modules/ events hosted by the Academy.

Target already exceeded.
As of 30 September 2018, under-represented content can be identified within 18 learning courses, modules and events hosted by the Academy. This is against the list of under-represented topics previously agreed with DFID.
Under-represented content identified within 3 learning courses/ modules/ events hosted by the Academy.
Under-represented content identified within more than 3 learning courses/ modules/ events hosted by the Academy.

description.narrative: 5. Sector leader in promoting innovative learning design, MEAL/assessment, platform, delivery and evidence-based content.

comment.narrative: Three innovation pilots completed and partnerships formed with at least 2 organisations focused on new technologies or approaches.

Exceeded. To date the Academy has completed four innovation pilots, 1) a Train the Trainers Innovation Training Workshop conducted in Kenya (January 2017), 2) the Learning SHIFT (Scaling up Humanitarian Knowledge Integrating Fun and Technology) through Gamification Workshop in the Philippines (April 2017), 3) a Massive Open online Course (MOOC) on gamification for humanitarian learning (June-July 2017), and 4) a Gamification Workshop in Bangladesh (October 2017). The gamification MOOC attracted 1,100 learners.
Host Innovation conference or event for the sector featuring learning from innovation

Target achieved.
The Academy hosted a pre-conference ‘Innovations in Humanitarian Learning’ workshop at the eLearning Africa Conference in Kigali, Rwanda, in September 2018.
Innovation strategy finalised and operationalised; two innovation pilots scoped and commenced.

description.narrative: 4. Develop robust platforms to facilitate the exchange of learning, high-quality knowledge and evidence through engagement, collaboration, and thought leadership.

1. Academy facilitated knowledge, evidence and innovations utilised by users and organisations (disaggregated by location) in the sector to improve quality/scale of humanitarian response, preparedness and recovery

comment.narrative: Academy-facilitated knowledge and evidence outputs accessed at least 2,500 times by users (cumulative).
Complete: A total of 8,673 users are known to have accessed Academy-facilitated knowledge and evidence outputs.
Strategies scoped for knowledge search portal providing increased access to evidence and evaluation resources (cumulative).).
Strategies scoped for knowledge search portal providing increased access to evidence and evaluation resources (cumulative).
Academy-facilitated knowledge and evidence outputs accessed by at least 11,000 times by users (cumulative)

Target aleady exceeded.
Academy facilitated knowledge and evidence outputs were accessed by 14,407 users.

description.narrative: 5. Through its activities the Academy has demonstrated relevance to the humanitarian sector, and has strengthened the long-term sustainability of the Academy's impact
# of individuals engaged with an Academy learning course that indicate they found the course relevant to their work in the humanitarian sector

comment.narrative: 8,800 individuals engaged with Academy learning indicate that the content was relevant to their work in the humanitarian sector

Target already exceeded.
Relevance of the Academy’s offer was demonstrated by 22,657 learners indicating (through post-course user feedback surveys administered when a learner completes a course) that the material they engaged with was applicable to their day-to-day work activities and that the learning they engaged with will be applied in their work as a humanitarian worker/volunteer.

description.narrative: Number of humanitarian conferences the Academy has been invited to contribute to in 2018

comment.narrative: Academy is invited to attend at least 5 conferences on innovation and/or localisation in 2018

Target already exceeded.
From January 1 to September 30 the Academy accepted invitations to was attend 11 conferences specifically focusing on key themes of localisation and/or innovation. Representatives from the Academy attended, hosted and presented at 11 different events that were held in 8 different countries.

description.narrative: The number of organisations paying for services from the Academy

comment.narrative: At least 8 organisations are paying for access to the Academy's products, platforms or services

Target on track.
The Academy currently has 6 organisations paying for its services and products.

description.narrative: 6. The Academy has integrated value for money as a guiding operational value underpinning its work and ethos
% of the Academy's internal value for money indicators met

comment.narrative: The Academy meets at least 75% of its value for money indicator targets

Target on track.
This milestone will be reported on in March 2019 given several VFM indicators are measured on an annual basis. Systems and processes are already in place to facilitate embedding of VFM across the Academy’s operations (indicator 1), with the Academy’s VFM approach systematically shared with staff and partners.

description.narrative: 7. The Academy has taken steps towards improving the gender parity of individuals accessing humanitarian capacity-building resources
The Academy's Gender Working Group conduct analysis of the gender disparity among participants of learning facilitated by the Academy and use it to inform the Academy's decision-making.

comment.narrative: 15% of the Academy's communication campaigns spend is used for addressing the gender disparity of individuals accessing Academy products, platforms and services

Target already met.
15% of the Academy’s social media budget for the quarter was spent on uniquely targeting women that reached 31,441 unique individual women in event promotion, resulting in 401 event responses; 45,905 in course promotion with 2,077 following through with link clicks; and 7,656 views on a Wellness and Resilience interview with a humanitarian professional.

description.narrative: A wider and more diverse group of organisations and individuals (including more local organisations and emerging leaders) gain in credibility and influence on disaster preparedness, management response and decision-making.

Number of humanitarian actors (individuals and organisations) accessing Academy facilitated  Learning through Academy platform/Centres globally  (i.e., presence of Academy Centre and strategy in place) disaggregated by gender.
Increased professionalism and quality assured humanitarian skills more widely shared contributing to transformed community resilience and response by people in crisis affected countries.

% change in the level of international actor engagement (individuals deployed) during a major crisis versus national actor engagment as measured by the proportion of humanitarian individuals from outside versus inside the country responding) for Academy-focus countries.

comment.narrative: 5% decrease international engagement versus national over baseline
10% decrease international engagement versus national over baseline
15% decrease international engagement versus national over baseline
